Laboratory of Energy Environmental Catalysis, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China * Corresponding author Directional design of efficient catalysts for volatile organic compounds degradation remains a complex, yet effective and challenging process. Herein, oxygen-rich vacancy Co3O4-anchored Pt catalysts were prepared through atom-trapping strategy and relevant vacancy defect inductive effect was proposed. The 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst presented a reaction rate value of 32.2×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C for catalytic propane total oxidation, which was nearly 5 times the reaction rate of Co3O4 (6.7×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1). Also, it exhibited excellent water-resistance and catalytic stability. The Pt atoms were stabilized on the Co3O4 surface by vacancy defects to improve dispersion. Meanwhile, the vacancy defect inductive effect induced stronger electron interaction between Pt and Co3O4 on the surface, thus promote the redox ability at low-temperature. The mobility and oxygen-activating ability of surface lattice oxygen were also strengthened by the vacancy defect inductive effect. This facilitated the generation of more surface-active oxygen species for the cleavage of C-H bond and the deep oxidation of intermediate species. Overall, this study proposed a novel concept the fabrication of highly efficient catalysts for the purpose of catalytic oxidation. Graphical Abstract The oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co3O4 enhanced the dispersion of Pt species loading, thereby promoting synergistic catalytic effects between Pt and Co3O4 that significantly improve the propane total oxidation activity. Keywords Propane total oxidation Pt/Co3O4 Oxygen vacancy Defect inductive effect Synergetic catalysis 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are the predominant atmospheric contaminants, pose substantial threats to both ecosystem stability and public health [1]. VOCs are diverse and originating from a broad spectrum of sources [2]. Notably, short-chain alkanes, represented by propane, predominantly emanate from stationary industrial emitters and liquefied petroleum gas transport mobile combustion sources, serving as principal precursors for tropospheric ozone formation and secondary organic aerosols generation. [3]. Catalytic oxidation has been established as the benchmark remediation strategy for VOC abatement [4], with its efficacy fundamentally governed by the rational design and application of catalysts [5]. State-of-the-art catalytic systems predominantly employ platinum (Pt) metals, which demonstrate exceptional activity for VOC catalytic degradation. [6]. Due to its high cost, reducing the usage and cost is a major research focus in the environmental field [7]. The construction of Pt loaded non-precious metal oxide catalysts, can improve the noble metal dispersion while reducing the amount of noble metal [8]. Compared with TiO2, CeO2 and other auxiliary carriers, Co3O4 displayed outstanding redox properties, high oxygen mobility [9] and great propane oxidation catalytic activity [10] at low temperature. Meanwhile, Pt demonstrated excellent performance in activating oxygen molecules [11], which could form an excellent dual-active-site catalytic system with Co3O4 for propane oxidation. Xiong et al. [12] prepared Pt/Co3O4 catalysts with metal organic framework (MOF) as precursor, that exhibited elevated catalytic activity and stability for propane oxidation. These results were attributed to the excellent oxygen mobility and high surface chemisorbed oxygen species concentration [10]. It was found that improving Pt dispersion on the surface of Co3O4 and adjusting interfacial interactions could effectively enhance the catalytic activity. Atom-trapping strategy is considered to be one of the most effective ways to synthesize highly stable atomical catalysts [13]. Datye et al. [14] demonstrated that removing mobile surface species facilitates the effective trapping and atomic dispersion of platinum group metals. Li et al. [15] reported a Pt/Mn2O3 with abundant surface defects on the carrier surface through a selective dissolution strategy. He et al. [16] immobilized Pt on CeO2 oxygen vacancies through an atom-trapping strategy to construct a stable Pt-O-Ce active interface, and found that the interface near the defect promoted charge transfer in the active interfacial region due to the distortion. However, the current atom-trapping strategy is still limited to the active species-assistant structure. Therefore, it is significant to further explore to the dual-active-component system and the inherent influence of oxygen vacancies on the catalysis of Pt-Co3O4 for breaking through the low-temperature bottleneck. Herein, an atom-trapping strategy through reduction-anchoring path was used to construct highly dispersion Pt/Co3O4 catalysts (Pt/VO-Co3O4). By characterizations and catalytic tests, we focused on the effect of the oxygen vacancy on Pt and Co3O4 dual-active-site system. The structure-activity relationship between highly dispersion Pt species caused by vacancy defect inductive (VDI) effect and propane catalytic total oxidation activity was investigated by ex-situ X-ray spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Co3O4-PF Co3O4 catalyst with polyhedral framework (PF) structure (Co3O4-PF) was prepared with ZIF-67 as precursors [17]. Under magnetic stirring, 0.582 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR) was dissolved in 50 mL methanol (Sinopharm, AR) to form Solution A. And 0.616 g of 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm, Sinopharm, AR) was dissolved in 50 mL of methanol to prepare Solution B. Then Solution B was slowly added into Solution A with vigorous mixing. After 24 h of continuous stirring, the purple precipitate was centrifuged and washed it with methanol three times. ZIF-67 was then obtained after vacuum drying overnight at 60 °C. The synthesized ZIF-67 was oxidized in air at high temperature of 300 °C for 2 h (with a ramp of 2 °C·min–1) to obtain the Co3O4-PF catalyst. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Pt/Co3O4 Generally, 0.5 g of Co3O4-PF was weighed and dissolved in 100 mL of methanol as solution A, and a certain amount of Pt(acac)2 (Aladdin, AR) was weighed and dissolved in 10 mL of methanol as solution B. Solution B was added dropwise to solution A at room temperature, stirred for 24 h and then evaporated at 80 °C in an oil bath, and the product obtained was oven dried at 60 °C and oxidized at 300 °C for 2 h in an air atmosphere (with a controlled 2 °C·min–1 The Pt/Co3O4 catalysts with different Pt doping amounts were obtained. According to the Pt content measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) (Table S1), they were named as 0.3Pt/Co3O4, 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and 1.2Pt/Co3O4, respectively. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Vo-Co3O4 Weighed 1 g of synthetic Co3O4-PF and put it into the 10% H2/Ar atmosphere for 1 h of reduction at 200 °C (with a temperature rise rate of 2 °C·min–1) to acquire VO-Co3O4 catalysts. 2.1.4 Synthesis of Pt/Vo-Co3O4 The solution A was prepared by weighing 0.5 g of Vo-Co3O4 and dispersed it in 10 mL of methanol, and the solution B was prepared by a small amount of Pt(acac)2 dissolved in 10 mL of methanol. Then the solution B was added dropwise to the solution A at room temperature, stirred for 24 h and dried by rotary evaporator, slowly. The dried sample was oxidized at 300 °C for 2 h in the air atmosphere (control the heating rate of 2 °C·min–1). Then, the Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalysts with different Pt loading amounts were obtained. According to the Pt content measured by ICP-AES (Table S1), they were named as 0.3Pt/VO-Co3O4, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 and 1.2Pt/VO-Co3O4, respectively. 2.1.5 Synthesis of Pt/SiO2 1 g SiO2 (40-60 mesh, Sinopharm, AR) was weighed and dispersed into methanol. Under strong stirring condition, a small amount of Pt(acac)2 was added at room temperature. stirred for 24 h and dried by rotary evaporator. The dried sample was oxidized at 100 °C for 1 h in the air atmosphere (control the heating rate of 2 °C·min–1). Then, the Pt/SiO2 catalysts with different Pt loading amounts were obtained. The Pt content was measured by ICP-AES and listed in Table S1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffractometer (XRD) was obtained through Bruker D8 Advance. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was measured with a Micromeritics ASAP2010 instrument by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method. ICP-AES was analyzed with Agilent Instruments’ ICPOES 730 analyzer to quantitatively determine element content. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was recorded on a Hitachi S-4800 apparatus. transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were collected on a JEM-2100UHR instrument. Raman was collected on a ThermoFisher DXR microscope. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and electron spin resonance (ESR) experiments were conducted on a Bruker A300 spectrometer. X-ray absorption near edge structures of (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectrum (EXAFS) were measured at the 14W1 workstation of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF), and the monochromator was Si(111). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured on a Shimadzu AXIS SUPRA+ electronic energy spectrum, the steps and details of peak fitting are detailed in Supporting Information. CO chemical adsorption was performed on an Autochem II 2920 apparatus. O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were performed on a Quantachchrome Chembet Pulsar apparatus. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTs) were obtained on a Bruker V80 instrument equipped with an MCT/A detector and a ZnSe in-situ cell. More details are presented in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Evaluation of propane catalytic degradation The catalytic activity in the total propane was measured using 200 mg of the catalyst (40–60 mesh) in a fixed bed reactor. A gas with flow rate of 100 mL·min−1 (GHSV: 30000 h−1) mixture consisted of 2500 ppm C3H8 and air as the balance gas. The inlet and outlet gas were monitored and analysed online using a Fuli instrument GC-9720 gas chromatograph for VOC detection. (9): (9) E ads = E adsorbate+surface – E surface – E gas More DFT calculation details are listed in Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural characteristics The highly dispersion Pt/VO-Co3O4 were fabricated with an atom-trapping strategy through reduction-anchoring path (Fig. 1(a) ). As reference sample, Pt/Co3O4 synthesized by ordinary impregnation method (Fig. S1), and the optimal loading content of Pt (0.6%) was preliminarily screened through activity evaluation (Figs. S2 and S3). MOF materials have unique network coordination structures, with metal ions as connection points and organic ligand supports constitute 3D spatial extension. This is beneficial for the uniform distribution of metal sites in catalytic materials. Therefore, using ZIF-67 as a precursor, the obtained Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 derivatives can inherit the morphology and structural advantages of the precursor, thereby enhancing the dispersibility of active ingredient and enhance the adsorption capability of the material to the reactant [18]. The main diffraction patterns of both 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 displayed a typical Co3O4 cubic spinel structure in XRD patterns (PDF#74-2120) (Fig. S4) [19]. The absence of Pt-related XRD features originated from trace Pt loading with atomic dispersion [20]. Compared to 0.6Pt/Co3O4, the diffraction peaks of the 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst after H2 reduction became slightly weaker and wider, which was due to the amorphization caused by the generation of surface oxygen vacancies [21]. However, a non-significant disparity was observed in the lattice parameters and grain size results (Table S1), indicating that H2 treatment had barely impact on the Co3O4 bulk structure. In view of the constraints imposed by the ZIF-67 precursor, the formation of a carbon-nitrogen bond was achieved through the process of heat treatment under controlled atmosphere. Both 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 samples were revealed typical rhomboid dodecahedral morphology with an average diameter of approximately 500 nm in SEM (Figs. 1(b), S5(a)). Similar homogeneous structures of 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalysts also exhibited similar specific surface area and pore volume (Fig. S6, Table S2) [22]. Compared to 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4, some agglomerated particles were observed at the edge of the structure in TEM images of 0.6Pt/Co3O4 (Figs. 1(c), S5(b)). Moreover, the (220) crystal planes of Co3O4 were observed in HRTEM images of both 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (Fig. 1(d)) and 0.6Pt/Co3O4 (Fig. S5(c)) [23]. Besides, additional Pt (110) crystal plane belonging to PtO2 was observed at the edge of 0.6Pt/Co3O4 [24], which implied that the Pt was agglomerated to form particles on the 0.6Pt/Co3O4 surface rather than being highly dispersed on the surface of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4. Moreover, the EDS-mapping and high-resolution HAADF-STEM analysis revealed the highly dispersed characteristic of Pt nanoparticles on Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface (Figs. 1(e), 1(f)). In contrast, Pt species exhibited a larger particle distribution on the surface of Pt/Co3O4 (Figs. S5(d), S5(e)). Since EDS-mapping analysis revealed homogeneous dispersion of Pt nanoparticles across both Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 samples, advanced characterization should be acquired to elucidate the atomic-level coordination of Pt species. XANES of Co K-edge displays that the 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst possess a lower white line peak intensity than Pt/Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 2(a) ), representing that the Co atom in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst possessed a smaller number of occupied electronic states. From the Fourier transform (FT) k 3-weigted EXAFS, the Co-O bond in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst was slightly longer than that of 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and Co3O4 (Fig. 2(b)). Meanwhile, the 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst also exhibited larger lattice spacing than 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4 (Fig. S7), signifying that Pt was confined around vacancy on the surface by the inductive effect so as to boost the dispersion, and Pt atoms could enter the lattice of Co3O4 to form a more compact structure [25]. The Pt L3-edge XANES was undertaken for further determining the Pt atom coordination in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 2(c)). The Pt absorption edge energy and white line intensity revealed that the Pt species on 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface presented more positively positive charge than 0.6Pt/Co3O4 catalyst [26]. Furthermore, different from the peaks in 0.6Pt/Co3O4 catalyst were corresponding to PtO2, the Pt species on 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface displayed a shell situation similar to that of Co atom in Co3O4 (Fig. 2(d)), implying that the Pt entered the Co3O4 lattice. The high dispersion of Pt originates from the defect-induced effects in VO-Co3O4 (Fig. S8). Due to the strong reduction of surface Co3O4 by hydrogen, a significant amount of surface lattice oxygen and coordinated Co atom is removed, generating abundant surface vacancies and defects. During Pt loading, these defect sites exhibited stronger attraction toward Pt, formed a VDI effect, directing its deposition near defect regions. With the occurrence of secondary oxidation process, the VDI effect facilitated the formation of Co3O4 lattice structures around the Pt sites. 3.2 Surface chemical properties Clearer surface defect structure was analyzed through EPR spectra and Raman spectra. EPR spectra revealed that due to the anchoring effect of oxygen vacancies, Pt was indeed dispersed on the defect location, resulting in a slight decrease in oxygen vacancy content (Fig. 3(a) ) [27]. Meanwhile, by comparing Pt/Co3O4 with Co3O4, the Pt loading was conducive to the oxygen vacancies formation on surface due to the weakening of Pt-O bonds [28]. The Raman technique was used to measure the surface Co-O bond strength (Fig. 3(b)), five peaks at around 470, 510, 180, 610 and 680 cm–1, could be compatible with the E g, F 2g, F 2g, F 2g and A 1g vibration modes of spinel Co3O4 [12]. When oxygen vacancies generated, the Raman peaks of VO-Co3O4 were shifted red. According to the Hooke's Law [29], the vacancies presence led to a decrease in the Co-O bond force constant (Fig. 3(c)), which was beneficial for improving the surface oxygen mobility [30]. XPS spectra were used to analyze the elemental composition and chemical states of Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalysts. Co 2p spectra generated asymmetric Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 peaks at 781 and 795 eV, respectively. Deconvolution of the peaks reveals that the peaks corresponding to the 2p orbital binding energy of Co3+ (779.6, 794.8 eV) and Co2+ (781.2, 796.4 eV) [31]. And the content of Co3+ and Co2+ was obtained. Due to the generation of oxygen vacancies, a large amount of Co on the surface of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4 catalysts was in a coordination unsaturated state, resulting in a significant reduction in the Co3+ content [32]. However, the introduction of Pt increased the Co3+/Co2+ ratio (Fig. 3(d), Table S3), indicating that the Pt loading will strengthen the coordination of surface Co and O [33]. Based on the O 1s spectra, the asymmetric O 1s peaks can be divided into three components at 529.6, 530.5, and 531.3 eV (Fig. 3(e)), corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface hydroxyl oxygen (Osur) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively. There was more Oads species on 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface [34]. Pt 4d XPS spectra can be divided into 317 and 332 eV peaks, belonging to the Pt 4d 5/2 and Pt 4d 3/2 orbitals, respectively. And four peaks can be obtained after further fitting, that represented to Pt2+ (317.1, 331.7 eV) and Pt4+ (319.3, 333.2 eV) species [35]. Compared to 0.6Pt/Co3O4, the number of Pt electrons in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 was increased (Fig. 3(f)). The Pt atom in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 exhibited a lower valence state, originating from the VDI effect mediated incorporation of Pt species into the Co3O4 lattice, where they adopt valence states analogous to Co ions instead of the PtO2 structure in 0.6Pt/Co3O4 [36]. Meanwhile, the weaken Pt-O bond contributed considerably to the activation of Osur species [37]. Both 0.6Pt/Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 O2-TPD profiles exhibited lower temperature for chemical adsorption oxygen (O2 – and O–) desorption (250–350 °C) than Co3O4 (Fig. 3(g)) [38]. Besides, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 possessed approximate temperature and amount of Olatt desorption (Table S4), representing a stronger surface oxygen migration capacity [39]. ESR experiments were attained to identify the differences in the ability of catalysts to activate oxygen and generate free radicals. Six obvious ESR signals appeared under visible light indicated the formation of O2 – (Fig. 3(h)) [40]. Based on the ESR signal intensity, t the catalytic activity toward oxygen activation follows this descending order 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 > 0.6Pt/Co3O4 > VO-Co3O4 > Co3O4, demonstrating that the Pt loading was significantly benefited to O2 molecules activation. The Pt loading typically results in an improvement of low-temperature redox capacity. [41]. There were two notable peaks in H2-TPR profiles of Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4 at 340 °C and 420 °C, corresponding to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0 [42], individually (Fig. 3(i)). Moreover, an additional peak appeared at low temperature (260 °C) after Pt loading, which was attributed to the reduction of Pt4+ [43]. Combining the excellent reducibility of Pt and high surface lattice oxygen mobility, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 exhibited maximum low-temperature hydrogen consumption (Table S5). 3.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The synthesized Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalysts were tested for propane total oxidation, and exhibited greatly selectivity (Table S6). The propane catalytic performance evaluation is displayed in Fig. 4(a) , and relevant activity data was calculated and listed in Table S7. Compared to 0.6Pt/SiO2 (6.4×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C) and Co3O4 (6.7×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1), the dual-active-site combination of Pt and Co3O4 can effectively enhance the propane catalytic activity, 0.6Pt/Co3O4 displayed a reaction rate of 17.6×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C. Meanwhile, the high dispersibility of Pt in 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4, which originated from the VDI effect, could further enhance the catalyst's ability to degrade propane total oxidation. The 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst possessed the best catalytic activity, even compared to the propane catalytic activities, especially Pt-based and Co3O4-based catalysts, reported in other literatures (Table S8). The propane reaction rate of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 was 32.2×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C, almost 4 times higher than those of 0.6Pt/SiO2 and Co3O4 and twice as high as that of Pt/Co3O4 (17.6×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1). By comparing the reaction rates of Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4 (17.3×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1), it could be observed that the oxygen vacancies could triple the reaction rate at low temperature. When Pt was anchored near oxygen vacancies, although the number of oxygen vacancies decreased, the synergistic catalysis between Pt and Co3O4 delivered more significant improvement of catalytic activity. Meanwhile, the specific surface activity (SSA) of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (41.9×10–8 mol·m–2·s–1) at 160 °C was almost 3 times higher than that of Co3O4 (9.6×10–8 mol·m–2·s–1) and almost twice as high as that of Pt/Co3O4 (22.9×10–8 mol·m–2·s–1) (Fig. S9), which could be attributed to the catalyst structure inherited from the MOF precursor. Moreover, the TOFs of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (5.4×10–3 s–1) was higher than that of 0.6Pt/Co3O4 (4.0×10–3 s–1) at 160 °C (Fig. S10), indicating that the enhancement of Co3O4 and Pt active sites by the VDI effect was decisive to the catalytic performance improvement. The calculated activation energy (E a) revealed that the introduction of Pt outstandingly enhanced the intrinsic activity of the catalyst, as compared with the E a of VO-Co3O4 (36.5 kJ·mol–1) and Co3O4 (38.1 kJ·mol–1). The E a of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 and 0.6Pt/Co3O4 were 28.8 and 29.1 kJ·mol–1, respectively (Fig. S11), demonstrating that the increased activity was predominantly attributable to the influence of Pt loading, as opposed to the generation of oxygen vacancies on surface. Moreover, the catalytic stability was evaluated. Upon introduction of 5% water vapor, the catalytic activity of the catalyst was slightly weakened (Fig. 4(b)), because of the propane and water competitive adsorption [44]. The resistance to water of the catalysts was in the order of 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 > 0.6Pt/Co3O4 > Co3O4 (Fig. 4(c)). Moreover, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 displayed excellent long-term stability (Fig. S12), crystal stability (Fig. S13), structure stability (Fig. S14) and value states stability (Fig. S15, Table S9). Besides, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited a better high-low temperature change stability (Fig. S16) and cycle stability (Figs. S17, S18) than 0.6Pt/Co3O4 catalyst. The structure-property correlation between catalytic activity and surface species ratio (Figs. 4(d), S19) was investigated. Firstly, higher Co3+/Co2+ ratio caused by Pt loading was conducive for absorption and activation of reactional molecules [44]. And the electron transformation between Pt and Co enhanced the low-temperature reducibility of Co active sites for catalytic oxidation of propane, strengthening the Co3+/Co2+ redox cycle [45]. Moreover, due to the improvement of surface oxygen mobility caused by the VDI effect, more Oads on Co3O4 surface were generated by activating oxygen molecules [12]. The Oads exhibited high oxidability to break C–H and C–C bond through a nucleophilic reaction, thereby facilitating the low-temperature propane oxidation [29]. 3.4 Kinetic investigation Further kinetic research to reveal the impact of the Pt dispersibility caused by the VDI effect on catalytic behavior. Firstly, reaction rate based on Pt mass content was normalized to analyze the structure activity correlation between Pt support and catalytic activity. In the both Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4, the reaction rates shown a trend that first increased and then decreased with the increase of Pt content (Table S10), indicating that the Pt dispersion form has a significant impact on catalytic performance [46]. A small amount of Pt highly dispersion is conducive to form more adsorption and activation sites. Meanwhile, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (R Pt-160 = 22.3×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1) displayed a higher react rate than Pt/Co3O4 (R Pt-160 = 10.9×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1), confirmed the enhancement of Pt active sites by the VDI effect. The dual-active-site combination of Pt and Co3O4 also makes the catalytic activity of Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst exceed that of most catalysts reported in public references (Table S11). Moreover, kinetic studies on Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalysts were conducted to further investigated the enhancement of Pt dispersibility caused by the VDI effect on catalytic activity. All kinetic data were measured under conversion rates below 15%, thus ignoring the impact of the product. By adjusting the inlet ratios of propane, air, and nitrogen, the dependence of reaction rate on the partial pressure of propane and oxygen was investigated separately [47]. Specifically, we fixed the oxygen partial pressure to 8.08 kPa and obtained the numerical value of the reaction rate changing with the propane partial pressure (Table S12). Due to the large size and weak polarity of propane, it exhibits weak adsorption on both Pt and Co3O4 surfaces, resulting in a high reaction order [48]. Therefore, propane exhibited similar reaction orders (0.99–1.01) at all catalyst interfaces (Figs. 5(a) , 5(b) and Figs. S20(a), S20(b)). Unlike propane, there are significant differences in the performance of oxygen (Table S13). The oxygen reaction order on Pt/SiO2 (–0.57) was well below those on Co3O4 (–0.86) and VO-Co3O4 (–0.84) (Fig. 5(c)), implying that the behavior of oxygen adsorbed and activated on Pt site was different from that on Co3O4 surface. After Pt loading, the reaction order approached –0.6 to –0.7 (Fig. 5(d), Figs. S20(c), S20(d)). Based on the results, the O2 pulse experiment was acquired to investigate the O2 adsorption and activation behavior on Pt and Co3O4 site at low temperature. After pulse oxygen injection, propane concentration gradually decreases (Fig. S21). Due to the low temperature (140 °C), O2 was mainly activated as O2 - and O– species to react, instead of lattice oxygen reaction [22]. According to the C3H8 oxidation conversion capacity and catalytic rate, the order of oxygen activation ability was 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 > 0.6Pt/Co3O4 > VO-Co3O4 ≍ Co3O4, proving that the adsorption and activation ability of O2 molecular both strengthened with the Pt species at low-temperature [49], and demonstrating that the VDI effect significantly augmented the oxygen activation capacity of platinum catalysts. At this point, the expression of apparent rates based on power series have been acquired (Table 1 ). The apparent rate constants on Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/VO-Co3O4 were much higher than those on Pt/SiO2, Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4, also demonstrating that the recombination of Pt-Co3O4 dual-active-sites greatly improves the intrinsic kinetic activity. Besides, the apparent rate constant on 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (5.99) was almost twice that on 0.6Pt/Co3O4 (3.50), that could be due to the enhanced interaction between Pt and Co3O4 caused by the VDI effect [35]. 3.5 In-situ DRIFT spectroscopy In-situ DRIFTs technique elucidated dynamic evolution of surface intermediates across catalytic systems. Beyond characteristic C–C/C–H vibrations (2930–2850 cm–1) from propane adsorption (Table S14) [50], the oxygenated intermediates manifested distinct vibrational signatures on Co3O4 (Fig. 6(a) ), VO-Co3O4 (Fig. 6(b)), 0.6Pt/Co3O4 (Fig. 6(c)) and 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (Fig. 6(d)) surface, including (1) carboxylates and carbonates with hydroxyl species (υ(OH)), (2) carbonyl groups (υ(C–O), υ(C=O)), and (3) carboxylates (υ as(COO–), υ s(COO–), δ(O–C–O)) [30,51–53]. Combined with related literatures [12,22,44,46,54], possible intermediate species and reaction pathways (Eqs. (10)–(29)) were proposed. (10) Co2+ + O2(g) → 2(Co3+ – O–) (11) Pt0 + O2(g) → (Pt2+ – 2O–) (12) Pt2+ – O* + Co2+ → Pt0 + (Co3+ – O–) (13) CH3CH2CH3 + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3CH(OH)CH3 + Co2+ (14) CH3CH(OH)CH3(ads) + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3COH(OH)CH3 + Co2+ (15) CH3COH(OH)CH3(ads) → CH3COCH3 + H2O (16) CH3COCH3 + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3COOCH3 + Co2+ (17) CH3COOCH3 + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3CO + CH3O + Co2+ + H2O (18) CH3CO + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3OCO + Co2+ (19) CH3OCO + (Co3+ – O–) → CH3O + Co2+ + CO2 (20) CH3O + (Co3+ – O–) → HCO + Co2+ + H2O (21) HCO + (Co3+ – O–) → Co2+ + CO2 + H2O (22) CH3CH2CH3 + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3CH(OH)CH3 + Pt0 (23) CH3CH(OH)CH3(ads) + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3COH(OH)CH3 + Pt0 (24) CH3COCH3 + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3COOCH3 + Pt0 (25) CH3COOCH3 + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3CO + CH3O + Pt0 + H2O (26) CH3CO + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3OCO + Pt0 (27) CH3OCO + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → CH3O + Pt0 + CO2 (28) CH3O + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → HCO + Pt0 + H2O (29) HCO + (Pt2+ – 2O–) → Pt0 + CO2 + H2O In contrast, VO-Co3O4 displayed a similar in-situ DRIFTs signal to Co3O4 (Fig. 6(e)). The presence of oxygen vacancies slightly enhances the generation C–O and COO species at low temperature. However, the 0.6Pt/Co3O4 catalyst displayed a stronger deep oxidation ability towards propane intermediates than Co3O4 and VO-Co3O4, depending on the stronger oxygen activation ability at low temperatures, which was enhanced by Pt loading [55]. By contrasting 0.6Pt/Co3O4 with 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 (Fig. 6(f)), the VDI effect further improved the ability of Pt species to deeply oxide the COO bond, leading to a more noteworthy improvement of C–O bond peak intensity was acquired. The highly dispersed Pt species caused by the VDI effect could be attributed to the participation of more reactive oxygen species and great acceleration of the breaking of C–C bonds [56]. 3.6 DFT calculation The influence of the VDI effect on surface atomic structure was further verified by DFT calculation. An obvious electron transfer from Pt to Co3O4 could be observed in the charge density difference (Figs. 7(a) , 7(b)). Comparatively, the SMSI effect between Pt doping on the surface of Co3O4 with oxygen vacancy (Pt/VO-Co3O4) was stronger than that of Pt loading on Co3O4 surface (Pt/Co3O4), which was also confirmed by the enhanced Pt–O effect in the electron localization function (ELF) diagram (Fig. S22). Meanwhile, the d-band center of Co in the projected density of states (PDOS) shifted to Fermi level after Pt loading (Fig. S23) [57]. Meanwhile, the Pt d-band center of Pt/Co3O4 was far from Fermi level than that of Pt/VO-Co3O4 (Fig. 7(c)), for the reason that the Pt atom inserted into the Co3O4 surface lattice, resulting in a decrease in energy. Additionally, the Pt in Pt/Co3O4 exhibited a lower Bader electron number than that of Pt/VO-Co3O4 accurately described the electron transfer between Pt and Co3O4 (Fig. S24, Table S15) [58]. Meanwhile, the Pt/Co3O4 exhibited a reduced work function subsequent to the VDI effect driven incorporation of Pt species into the Co3O4 lattice (Fig. S25), indicating that the Pt/Co3O4 heterostructure structure was more conducive to surface electron excitation. The regulation of Pt entering Co3O4 lattice by the VDI effect had a significant impact on the adsorption and activation of surface oxygen species. Because of the lattice distortion caused by Pt entering Co3O4, the O coordinated with Pt on the Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface possessed a lower oxygen vacancy generation energy (2.07 eV) (Fig. S26) than that of Co3O4 (2.75 eV) and Pt/Co3O4 (2.25 eV), so that could be easily transformed into reactive oxygen species. Besides, the O2 molecules could spontaneously adsorb on all the Co3O4 (–0.25 eV), Pt/VO-Co3O4 (–0.44 eV) and Pt/Co3O4 (–0.33 eV) surface (Fig. 7(d)). And the energy change results of the AIMD kinetic simulation (Fig. S27) with large amount of O2 molecules adsorbed on the surface discovered that Pt/VO-Co3O4 exhibited stable and efficient adsorption capabilities toward O2 molecules (Fig. 7(e)) [59]. Meanwhile, the O dissociation energies were calculated by nudged elastic band theory method for locating the transition state (Fig. S28). Due to the enhanced synergistic catalytic capability between Pt and Co caused by the VDI effect, a lower oxygen dissociation energy was observed in Pt/VO-Co3O4 (0.71 eV) than Co3O4 (1.17 eV) and Pt/Co3O4 (0.81 eV) surface, indicating that the VDI effect induced a pronounced augmentation in the synergistic oxygen activation efficacy of the Pt/ Co3O4 heterojunction. Moreover, the behavior of C3H8 was also subjected to simulation. The order of the C3H8 adsorption energies on the surface is Pt/VO-Co3O4 (–0.29 eV) < Pt/Co3O4 (–0.18 eV) < Co3O4 (–0.09 eV) (Fig. S29). Due to the properties of molecular size and polarity, propane exhibited weak chemical adsorption on all three surfaces. However, the energy center of C3H8 adsorbed on Pt/VO-Co3O4 was much closer to Fermi level than those on Co3O4 and Pt/Co3O4 (Fig. 7(f)). Combined with the Bader charge analysis (Fig. S30, Table S16), the C3H8 transfers more electrons to the catalyst surface after adsorption on Pt/VO-Co3O4 surface. Besides, the structural modifications in C–C bond lengths and C–C–C bond angles following adsorption provide conclusive evidence for the pronounced activation of propane molecules at the Pt/VO-Co3O4 interface (Table S17). According to the literatures [22], the intermediate products of alcohols and esters formed by propane are easily deeply oxidized by reactive oxygen species. Therefore, based on the reaction mechanism, the intermediate transition state energies and the reaction barrier energies were calculated (Fig. S31). The rate-limiting steps are the first C–H bond (C3H8 to C3H8O, ΔG1) and C–C bond (C3H6O2 to C2H3O and CH3O, ΔG4) activations. Pt/Co3O4 displayed both the lower energy barriers of ΔG 1 (0.62 eV) and ΔG 4 (0.41 eV) than those of Co3O4 (ΔG 1 = 0.96 eV, ΔG 4 = 0.68 eV) and Pt/Co3O4 (ΔG 1 = 0.77 eV, ΔG 4 = 0.53 eV) (Fig. 7(g)) illustrated that the VDI effect promoted the C3H8 oxidation capacity of Pt active-site on the surface, therefore, the doping of Pt at surface defect sites is more conducive to the catalytic reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, an atom-trapping strategy was adopted to prepare oxygen-rich vacancy Co3O4-anchored atomically dispersed Pt catalysts. And the influence of the VDI effect to propane catalytic oxidation was explored. Wherein, 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 presented the highest catalytic efficiency with a reaction rate value of 32.2×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C for catalytic propane total oxidation, which was nearly 5 times the reaction rate of Co3O4 (6.7×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1). Characterization and DFT calculation results discovered that the VDI effect improved dispersion of Pt on surface, and promoted electron interaction between Pt and Co3O4, made the Pt-Co3O4 surface possess a better redox ability at low-temperature. Meanwhile, the enhanced electronic activity of Pt accelerated the activation and migration of surface oxygen species, strengthened the synergistic catalysis of Pt and Co3O4 for propane. In summary, this study proposed a new concept for constructing an efficient dual-active-component catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Directional design of efficient catalysts for volatile organic compounds degradation remains a complex, yet effective and challenging process. Herein, oxygen-rich vacancy Co3O4-anchored Pt catalysts were prepared through atom-trapping strategy and relevant vacancy defect inductive effect was proposed. The 0.6Pt/VO-Co3O4 catalyst presented a reaction rate value of 32.2×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1 at 160 °C for catalytic propane total oxidation, which was nearly 5 times the reaction rate of Co3O4 (6.7×10–5 mol·gcat –1·s–1). Also, it exhibited excellent water-resistance and catalytic stability. The Pt atoms were stabilized on the Co3O4 surface by vacancy defects to improve dispersion. Meanwhile, the vacancy defect inductive effect induced stronger electron interaction between Pt and Co3O4 on the surface, thus promote the redox ability at low-temperature. The mobility and oxygen-activating ability of surface lattice oxygen were also strengthened by the vacancy defect inductive effect. This facilitated the generation of more surface-active oxygen species for the cleavage of C-H bond and the deep oxidation of intermediate species. Overall, this study proposed a novel concept the fabrication of highly efficient catalysts for the purpose of catalytic oxidation.
